Hi Pat,


> This may be a bit off charter, but I've been reading some well argued 
> articles that have names such as "Why is Singleton evil?" and at the top 
> of the list are troubles that the singleton pattern causes for unit 
> testing. (which is on topic.)
> 
> The usual suggestions for rewriting the code are offered, such as using 
> a factory class to allocate/create objects, and always always just 
> returning the one and only.

I haven't seen that suggestion all too often. And I agree that it's not 
a big advantage over a true Singleton (if I understand you correctly). 
There still is a small improvement, though: the class itself isn't 
coupled any longer to its singletoness, so it becomes easier to reuse.

Personally, I typically prefer the Just Create One pattern: 
http://butunclebob.com/ArticleS.UncleBob.SingletonVsJustCreateOne


> p.s. any hints of forums/lists where this topic could be explored would 
> be greatly appreciated. I've found lots of places where rookies can ask 
> how to use a HashMap, and lots where folks argue about JSRs, but I'm 
> really looking for somewhere where professional, experienced Java 
> developers can get answers to hard questions.

I highly recommend JavaRanch.com. Although it's originally targeted at 
greenhorns, we also have a lot of veterans discussing advanced topics 
there, especially in the OO forum where your question would be most 
welcome: 
http://saloon.javaranch.com/cgi-bin/ubb/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=forum&f=9

(In fact you might want to do a search first, because we discuss the 
Singleton pattern quite regularly...)

Disclaimer: I'm a Sheriff (Administrator) at JavaRanch, so I'm hardly 
objective.

Cheers, Ilja
